description: A general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and extraterrestrial life; stars, their evolution, and their final state as white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes; galaxies, quasars, large structures, background radiation, and big bang cosmology. Elementary algebra and geometry will be used. This course is not recommended for physical-science majors or engineering students.
name: SURVEY OF THE UNIVERSE

values.comments:
This course is a general overview of astronomical theories, designed for non-majors. The course progresses from the solar system and extraterrestrial life to the life cycles of stars and the structures of galaxies and the universe. It fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement, and has no prerequisites. The textbook used is The Cosmic Perspective 4e.

Students had mixed feelings about the course. Some thought the course was “good for a requirement,” while others felt that the material was rushed and difficult for non-majors to comprehend. Most students noted that the material was fascinating, causing sometimes “disturbing realizations” about the universe – but only “if you can stay awake” in lecture.   

Students agreed that Professor Aguirre was “not very enthusiastic” in lecture and not a particularly good speaker. They noted that Prof. Aguirre was “competent with his knowledge” and thorough with detail, but tended to “talk at” the students. All students agreed that the course would have been better if Prof. Aguirre had been more interactive.

Students complained of a time-consuming, “excessive” workload, which consisted of written and online homework, an observation lab, midterms, a final, and a term paper. The amount of work made the class “about getting it done versus learning the material.” Furthermore, material on problem sets and exams did not necessarily correlate with class discussions, making studying difficult. As such, students noted that the textbook was more informative than lectures.
